results.title: Bitter welcome
results.creator_credit: Irving Jacoby, Affiliated Film Producers and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of the difficulties encountered by a man recently discharged from a mental hospital; produced to promote understanding of this problem by the general public. Schuster is accepted by his boss as perfectly competent to do the job, but has some difficulty in overcoming the distrust and ignorance of his workmates, which hurt him considerably. His relationship with his wife is damaged by his suspicious attitude to her motives for remaining loyal to him, but he eventually realises the strength of their mutual love and accepts the fact that although not everyone will be on his side, there are some people on whom he can depend.

results.title: Bitter Surrender
results.brief_description: A documentary about an overlooked aspect of adoption, the experience of mothers who have surrendered or given up their children. Through the personal accounts of five women, it explores and exposes what the legally enforced secrecy surrounding adoption hides, that the majority of women who relinquish their children face seemingly unresolvable shame and grief.

results.title: Bitter Rice
results.creator_credit: Graham Chase, Cecil Holmes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This is a documentary examining the political struggle in the Philippines. It focuses on the life and exploits of Bernabe Buscayno, alias Kommanda Dante, legendary figure, founder of the New People’s Army, and long time defender of the people. This gripping film looks at Dante’s recent efforts to bring about political and economic change by establishing the People’s Livelihood Foundation - an open co-operative for rice farmers in Capas, which represents the people’s struggle to earn from their land … so far the struggle has been peaceful.

results.title: Bits and pieces
results.creator_credit: Simon Klaebe, Leisl Hillhouse and Emerald Films
results.brief_description: A seemingly innocent “neat freak” (Jeremy Callaghan) patiently, yet swiftly cleans his house, under the watchful eye of a dog who may or may not be the cause of the proliferation of waste. As the milkman arrives to replenish the bottles, the plot takes an unexpected twist.

results.title: Bismarck: Germany from blood and iron
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Malcolm B. Heyworth, Chatsworth Film Productions and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Western Civilization”.
Nationalism is a major force in modern history, and national unity has often been forged in war. This film traces the step-by-step creation of modern Germany and suggests its implications for the rest of the world. In 1815 there were thirty-nine separate German-speaking states in a confederation under Austrian leadership. By 1871 a united German nation was born, led by the northern state of Prussia and the man who was to be its first Chancellor - Otto Von Bismarck. Relaxing with two American friends, the architect of the new Germany recollects the steps which led up to unification, which is told in a series of flashbacks. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Bischoff's Mountain: an epitaph
results.brief_description: A montage of stills, showing a now disused and decaying tin mine on Bischoff’s Mountain in Tasmania. Also shows Waratah one of Tasmania’s ghost towns. The visuals are accompanied with an overlay of industrial noises and male voices - suggestive of the previous industrial life of the town.

results.title: Birthday in Regensburg: permanent parliament
results.brief_description: The 300th birthday of the Reichstag of Regensburg, a predecessor of the German parliamentary system, offered the occasion for a review of its effects on German history, its tasks and its organisation.

results.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Merry-go-round”.
Birth describes the steps in child delivery and the special characteristics of the new born. Simple drawings and other references to the animal world explain the general birth process, while animated illustrations showing the movement of the human embryo provide details on labour and anatomy. One sequence allows the viewer to witness the actual moment of a baby’s birth and the steps that follow. Commentary by Richard Carpenter, Melissa Docker. Animation by Barry Merritt. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Birth with Dr. R.D. Laing
results.creator_credit: Sam Pillsbury, Helen Brew and Media Insights
results.brief_description: Questions and challenges many aspects of modern childbirth practices. Poses such questions as: why do mothers have little say in the services that exist entirely for them? Why does this occasion for the celebration of life turn so often into an emotional and biological disaster? R. D. Laing talks about his ideas on childbirth. A group of mothers discuss their experiences in hospitals.

results.title: Birth rediscovered
results.brief_description: A documentary about childbirth at home. This program traces the experience, during the final 24 hours up to the birth of the child of a couple who have decided to have their baby at home.
